metadata.title: Core-sheath micro/nano fiber membrane with antibacterial and osteogenic dual functions as biomimetic artificial periosteum for bone regeneration applications

sections.text:
The traditional Chinese medicine icariin (ICA) and broad-spectrum antibacterial drug moxifloxacin hydrochloride (MOX) were introduced into a polycaprolactone core and gelatin shell, respectively, to develop osteogenic and antibacterial biomimetic periosteum by coaxial electrospinning. The physical properties, drug release, degradation, antibacterial property, in vitro and in vivo osteogenesis performances were investigated. Results demonstrated that stepwise and controlled drug release profiles were achieved based on the coreshell configuration and disparate degradation rate of PCL and gelatin. Only 20% ICA was released from this dual drug-loaded membrane after 1 month while the release of MOX was almost completed. Moreover, clear in vitro antibacterial effect and enhancement in osteogenic marker expressions including osteocalcin, type-I collagen expression, and calcium deposition were observed. Notably, the dual drug-loaded membrane displayed fascinating properties contributing to in vivo bone formation in terms of quality and quantity in a rabbit radius defect model. © 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
Key words: Periosteum; Electrospinning; Core-sheath fiber; Antibacterial; Bone regeneration
Bone defects, particularly critical sized, remain a major challenge in the clinical field.1 Periosteum plays indispensable roles in bone formation and defect healing. Natural periosteum consists of two layers: the outer layer contains collagen fibers, fibroblasts, and microvessels; the inner layer contains osteopro-
The authors declare that no competing interests are present, and there is no conflict of interest.

Please cite this article as: Gong M, et al, Core-sheath micro/nano fiber membra periosteum for bone regeneration applications. Nanomedicine: NBM 2019;17:1
genitor cells that contribute to normal bone growth, healing, and remodeling.2 However, the availability of natural periosteum is limited because it can only be surgically separated from the bones of individuals.3 This limitation underlines the clinical need to develop a new substitute that can mimic the natural periosteum's structure and functions. Recently, Natural tissue or cell sheets have emerged as new strategies to construct periosteal substitute.4 Nevertheless, the fabrication complexity and high cost of cellsderived periosteum has resulted in the urgency to facilitate the acquisition and convenient usage of artificial periosteum.
Electrospinning has gained widespread interests in flexible electronics,5–7 filtering,8,9 energy storage,10 and biomedical applications.11–14 Among them, electrospun-fiber-based biomaterials have been widely used in tissue regeneration owing to the structural similarity to an extracellular matrix (ECM), porous structure permeable to air and liquid, easy fabrication, and low cost. Furthermore, the small diameter and large draw ratio of
ne with antibacterial and osteogenic dual functions as biomimetic artificial 24-136, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nano.2019.01.002
electrospun fibers have provided the fibrous membrane with excellent flexibility,15 an essential property for artificial periosteum to cover the complex surface of bone grafts. However, over the past few years, the primary strategies in electrospun-fiber-based bone regeneration are primarily focused on the encapsulation of anti-infection16 or osteogenic agents (antibiotics,17 growth factors,18 and/or nanomaterials19,20). Because conventional osteogenic growth factors exhibit disadvantages of rapid degradation, high cost, and deactivation issues, it is unsurprising that the clinical use of these growth factors has been limited.21 Nanomaterials have been studied extensively in the medical field for applications of drugs and genes carriers,22 cancer therapy,23 gene therapy, antibacterial agents,24–28 antiviral agents,29 tissue engineering,30 medical diagnosis,31 medical imaging,32 etc., and have advanced the development of medicine and biology significantly.33 However, the biosafety of nanomaterials have always been the most concerning issue in recent years.34 Furthermore, studies that emphasized on the synergistic effect of antibacterial and osteogenesis in the process of bone regeneration are still in their infancy. Infections typically occur in the early stage of bone defect healing while osteogenesis is a long-term pathological activity after the inflammation period.17 Thus, the appropriate and sequential release of antibacterial and osteogenesis agents would be highly desirable for biomaterials to match with the process of bone tissue regeneration. In this study, the core-sheath fiber configuration was realized in time to endow the electrospun fibrous artificial periosteum with multifunctional and hierarchical drug release properties. The multifunctional artificial periosteum was obtained by coaxial electrospinning with encapsulation of moxifloxacin hydrochloride (MOX) in a gelatin shell and icariin (ICA) in a polycaprolactone (PCL) core. ICA, the primary component of the traditional Chinese medicine Herba Epimedium,35,36 was chosen as the osteogenic assistant to endow the artificial periosteum with osteoinductive property, while MOX was selected to provide the artificial periosteum with antibacterial property. Genipin, an excellent natural biosafety cross-linker, was used to crosslink the gelatin in the fiber shell owing to its fast degradation, as reported in our previous study.37 Both the coresheath configuration and the disparate degradation rate of PCL and gelatin can contribute to the hierarchical release of the two encapsulated drugs. This study aims to develop a multifunctional electrospun core-sheath fiber membrane and investigate its physical properties, in vitro antibacterial effect, biocompatibility, osteogenesis property, and in vivo osteogenic performance in a rabbit radius defect model. This work is expected to provide valuable information for the development of multifunctional fiber-based artificial periosteum.

sections.heading: Methods
sections.text:
The methods are described in detail in the Supplementary Material.
Fabrication of core-sheath fiber membranes
A core solution was prepared by mixing 9% (w/v) PCL solution and ICA solution (0.5 w/w% PCL). Further, 10% (w/v)
gelatin was dissolved in mixed solvents of 2, 2, 2-trifluoroethanol (TFE) and deionized water; MOX (5 w/w% gelatin) was subsequently added to the gelatin solution to obtain the shell solution. The shell and core solutions were extruded simultaneously through the coaxial spinneret. The no drug-loaded, MOX-loaded, ICA-loaded, and dual drug-loaded membranes were labeled as PG, PGM, PGI, and PGMI, respectively.
The electrospun membrane was immersed in genipin solution (2 w/w% in ethanol) to crosslink the gelatin in the fiber shell. The membranes labeled as PG, PGM, PGI, and PGMI were referred to as cross-linked membranes without special statement in the following section.

sections.heading: Physical properties characterization
sections.text:
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to characterize the morphology of the electrospun fibers. The fiber diameters, pore sizes, apparent density, and porosity of the membranes were measured and calculated according to previous studies' description.38 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100F) was used to confirm the core-sheath configuration of the electrospun fibers. Tensile test was conducted using the BOSE ElectroForce 3200 test instrument.39 The water contact angles (WCAs) of the membranes were measured using the SL200A contact angle analyzer (China).
Drug release and fiber degradation
The samples were incubated in 5 mL of phosphate buffer saline (PBS) at 37 °C. At specific time points, all the soaking solutions were collected and replaced with fresh PBS. High-performance liquid chromatography was used to quantify the drug content in PBS.40 The in vitro degradation evaluation of the electrospun membrane was performed simultaneously as the drug release tests.

sections.heading: In vitro antibacterial evaluation
sections.text: Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) and Pseudomonas aeruginosa (P. aeruginosa) suspensions were spread uniformly onto the agar plate; subsequently, the samples were pasted and incubated at 37 °C. The bacterial growth on the agar plate was observed directly after incubation for 12 h.

sections.heading: In vitro biocompatibility evaluation
sections.text: A thiazolyl blue tetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay41 was used to evaluate the cytotoxicity of the fibrous membrane to MC3T3-E1 cells. CCK-8 assay was used to evaluate the viabilities of MC3T3-E1 cells proliferated on different fibrous membranes. The cell-cultured matrix was observed with SEM and confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM, Leica SP8) to evaluate the morphology of cells on the membrane.

sections.heading: Osteogenic differentiation of MC3T3-E1
sections.text:
The osteogenic differentiation markers expression including alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activities, osteocalcin (OCN), and type-I collagen (COL I), as well as the calcium deposition of MC3T3-E1 cells on the fibrous matrix were evaluated. At the determined time points, the cells on the fibrous matrix were lysed with the RIPA lysis buffer (Beyotime Biotechnology), and the
marker expressions were subsequently measured by the ALP assay kit (Nanjing, Jiancheng), collagen Type-I Elisa kit (Nanjing, Jiancheng) and mouse Osteocalcin Elisa kit (Nanjing, Jiancheng) separately, according to the manufacturer's instructions. For Ca2+ detection, the cell-cultured matrix was first stained with alizarin red solution (ARS) (0.2%, Solarbio, China) and subsequently 10% cetylpyridinium chloride (CPC) solution was used to desorb calcium ions. The absorbance of the solution was read at 540 nm, as reported in a previous study.42

sections.heading: Animals and surgical procedures
sections.text: The experimental protocol was approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee of Jishuitan Hospital. Further, 27 rabbits (New Zealand White, approximately 2.5 kg in weight) were divided randomly into three groups. The segmental defect in the middle radius of the right foreleg with a length of 1 cm was created. Kirschner wires were used to fix the two ends of the defects internally. The electrospun membranes were rolled into a column to cover the defect area and the two sides of the membranes were sewed up with the surrounding muscles (Figure S1). At 1, 2, and 3 months post-implantation, the rabbits were sacrificed by a lethal intravenous administration of sodium pentobarbital.

sections.heading: Radiographic evaluation
sections.text: At 1, 2, and 3 months post-implantation, the intact radii of each group were harvested and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde. The macroscopic regenerated status was examined by plain Xray observation and m-CT scanning. The bone mineral density (BMD) and bone volume fraction (bone volume/total volume, BV/TV) were measured in the region of interest.

sections.heading: Histological analysis
sections.text: The histological analysis of the regenerated bone tissue was performed as reported previously.43 Briefly, the samples were successively fixed, decalcified, dehydrated, embedded in paraffin, and sectioned to slices of 5 μm thickness. Hematoxylin–eosin staining (H&E staining) and Masson's trichrome staining were conducted on tissue sections according to the manufacturer's protocols. The tissue sections were subsequently observed under an optical microscope (CX21, Olympus, Japan).

sections.heading: Immunohistochemical analysis
sections.text: As for the immunohistochemistry analysis of the OCN expression, tissue sections were successively deparaffinized, rehydrated, submerged in hydrogen peroxide, incubated with 1% BSA, and incubated with primary antibody against OCN (ab13420, Abcam), followed by the application of HRP conjugated secondary antibody. Finally, the color was developed by the diaminobenzidine (DAB, Beyotime Biotechnology) kit and hematoxylin counterstaining. The tissue slices were observed under an optical microscope (CX21, Olympus, Japan).

sections.heading: Statistical analysis
sections.text:
All quantitative data were expressed as mean ± standard deviation. A statistical analysis was performed using the
OriginPro 8 software (Hampton, OriginLab). The student's t test was used to determine the statistical differences between PG and other groups. *p b 0.05 was regarded as statistically significant between independent groups.

sections.heading: Physical properties
sections.text:
The SEM micrographs of the coaxial-electrospun fibrous membranes indicated a randomly interconnected structure with no beads formed and a uniform distribution of micro/nano fibers (Figure 1, A). The TEM micrographs in Figures 1, B and S2, A clearly show the formation of the core-sheath configuration. The fiber morphology and porous structure were maintained after genipin crosslinking (Figure S2, B). The crosslinking decreased the fiber diameters slightly from the range of 500–1000 nm to 400–800 nm (Table S1). The dark component inside the fibers was PCL; it can be used as structural support for the fiber while the gelatin shell can provide biological cues for the fiber.
As shown in Figure 2, A, MOX and ICA are crystallized with characteristic peaks located at 6–8° and 32°, respectively. For the electrospun membranes, the diffraction peaks located at 23.8° and 24.2° were assigned to semi-crystallized PCL, and the base lines were upward owing to the amorphous gelatin in the fiber shell. The characteristic diffraction peaks of ICA and MOX were absent in the electrospun membranes, indicating the homogeneous dispersion of both drugs in the polymer matrix.
The stress–strain curves in Figure 2, B show that the membranes were stretchable, a significant property for the artificial periosteum to bear the stress during the surgical operation and physiological process. PGMI and PGM possessed the tensile strength of more than 1 MPa, which is comparable with natural periosteum,44 as demonstrated in Table S2.
As shown in Figure 2, C, all the core-sheath fiber membranes indicated excellent hydrophilicity with contact angles of 10°-60°. The addition of MOX in the fiber shell decreased the WCAwhile the ICA encapsulation slightly increased the WCA.

sections.heading: Drug release and degradation
sections.text:
As shown in Figure 3, A, approximately 50% MOX demonstrated a burst released from PGM and PGMI in the first 24 h; subsequently, a linear release until the 10th day was observed. Subsequently, a second burst release of MOX was observed until the 14th day. The release profiles of MOX from PGM and PGMI were similar, but the release of ICA from PGI and PGMI were different (Figure 3, B). Twenty percent of ICA was released from the PGMI while only 5% was released from the PGI matrix in the first 24 h. As shown in Figure 3, C, the release of MOX was much faster than that of ICA from PGMI during the whole investigation period. The release of MOX was almost completed at 1 month while a slow and sustained release for ICA was still continued.
The in vitro degradation behavior of the core-sheath fiber membrane is shown in Figure 3, D. All the fiber membrane exhibited evident mass loss during the 2 months. The degradation rates of all the membranes were as follows: PGM
NPGMI NPG NPGI. Approximately 60–80% of weight loss was achieved after 2 months of degradation for all the fiber membranes. Figure 3, E shows the morphology of the coresheath fiber membranes after degradation in PBS for 1 and 2 months. After 1 month degradation, the fiber surfaces of all membranes became rough and fractures were present only on the surface of the PGM fiber; after 2 month degradation, more fractures emerged on the surface of all the fibers compared to that of 1 month, but the general architecture of the fibers and porous structure was still preserved.

sections.heading: In vitro antibacterial activity and biocompatibility
sections.text:
As shown in Figure 4, A, no inhibition zone was observed around PG and PGI for both S. aureus and P. aeruginosa; the bacterial propagated quickly on the agar plates and finally the whole plate was covered by bacteria. Meanwhile, distinct inhibition zones were observed both around PGM and PGMI.
As shown in Figure 4, B, MC3T3-E1 cells displayed excellent growing status with RGR N100% during the first 2 days for all membranes; the RGR of MC3T3-E1 cultured in the extracts of these four membranes slightly decreased at the 3rd day but were still higher than 80%. MC3T3-E1 cells also exhibited healthy morphology as spindle shapes after they were cultured in the extracts of the electrospun core-sheath fiber membrane for 24 h (Figure 4, C).
Adherence and proliferation are the first-phase behavior of the cells to interact with biomaterials. After cultured for 4 h, the cells adhered to the electrospun membrane successfully (Figure 4, D). PGM displayed the greatest potential to promote MC3T3E1 proliferation among all membranes (Figure 4, E). There was no obvious facilitation influence of PGI on MC3T3-E1 proliferation compared with PG. However, the cell numbers on
all fiber membranes were increased during the 7 day culture. The morphology of the cells cultured on PGMI for 1, 3, 5, and 7 days indicated that the cells were growing healthily and could spread on the surface of the membrane without infiltrating into the thickness direction owing to the small pore size (Figure 4, F, G). After being cultured for 7 days, the cells formed a confluent layer almost covering the whole surface of the membrane.

sections.heading: In vitro osteogenic performances
sections.text:
Figure 5, A shows the ALP concentration secreted by MC3T3-E1 cells cultured on different fiber membranes. Significantly higher ALP concentrations on the fiber membrane supported groups were detected compared to that on TCP. PGI demonstrated the most effective performance in promoting ALP secretion among all the fiber membranes. The encapsulation of MOX in PGM and PGMI resulted in a lower ALP expression than PG. The highest OCN expression was achieved in the PGMI groups than in the TCP and other membrane groups (Figure 5, B). The incorporation of both MOX and ICA demonstrated a positive effect on OCN expression; thus, the highest OCN concentration was detected in the PGMI groups. COL I is an important structural component in the bone matrix and affects the mineralized tissue's strength and toughness significantly.45 No significant difference for the COL I expression was observed among the different groups after 14 days of culture (Figure 5, C). However, a higher COL I concentration on the PGMI group was detected compared to that on TCP and other three membrane groups after 21 days of culture. As shown in Figure 5, D, more calcium was deposited on PGI and PGMI compared with the samples without ICA at day 14. After 21 days of culture, considerable facilitation effect on calcium deposit was observed for all fiber membranes other than that on TCP, among which
PGMI possessed the greatest potential in encouraging calcium deposition.

sections.heading: Radiographic observation
sections.text:
The radiographic observation of the regenerated bone is shown in Figure 6. Nascent bone first emerged in the area adjacent to the ulna. More bony union formed in the membranetreated groups at 1 and 2 months post-surgery. After 3 months, an evident incomplete regeneration of nascent bone in the defect area was observed in the blank and PG groups; by contrast, much more compact bone formation was achieved in the PGMI group, which was also confirmed by 3D micro-CT scanning. As shown in Figure 6, B, substantial new bone was formed in all groups after 3 months post-transplantation. For the untreated group, a clear vacancy was observed in the purple part and the newly formed connected area with the host bone demonstrated a honeycomb. For the membrane-treated group, a much more compact and smooth surface of the newly formed bone was observed compared with the untreated groups. The quantity of the newly formed bone was also calculated by morphometric analysis (Figure 6, C, D). The BMD values of the regenerated
bone corresponded to the BV/TV for each group. The application of the electrospun membrane increased the BMD and BV/TV significantly compared with the blank group. Among all the three groups, the PGMI group displayed the highest value in promoting the quantity of the newly formed bone.

sections.heading: H&E and Masson's trichrome staining
sections.text:
As shown in Figure 7, A, 1 month post-implantation, bone marrow cavity had formed for the membrane-treated group while fat vacuoles were present in the defect area of the blank groups. More bone trabecular was formed in the PGMI group than in the PG group. Two months after transplantation, the number of bone trabecular was increased in the membrane-treated groups. Normal and regular bony trabecular, cartilage, and mature bone marrow cavity were observed 3 months post-implantation in the PGMI group. The blank control group resulted in the least bone trabecular andmature bone marrow cavity. Further, new cancellous bonewas observed to fill the defects of the PG groups, but the numbers of trabecular and mature bone marrow cavity were less than those of the PGMI group. The result from H&E staining indicated the excellent osteoinductivity of the dual drug-loaded electrospun core-sheath fiber membrane. Masson's trichrome staining was also used to evaluate the formation of COL I in vivo and the results are
shown in Figure 7, B. COL I was stained blue while the skeletal was stained red. One month post-implantation, abundant fat vacuoles were observed in the defect area of the untreated group, and the result was in accordance with that from H&E staining. For the membrane-treated groups, collagen fibers were observed in the form of fibrous tissues. Two months post-implantation, COL I in the bone matrix had been observed in both the membrane-treated groups. Three months post-implantation, the PGMI treated group
resulted in more COL I expression, bone trabecular, and mature bone marrow cavity compared with the PG and untreated group, indicating the great potential of PGMI fibrous membrane as an artificial periosteum.

sections.heading: Immunohistochemical analysis
sections.text:
The OCN expression is the marker of bone maturation and is indicated as the brown area in Figure 8. Although the
expression of OCN was detected in all groups, the expression extent differed, as revealed by the staining area and intensity. The expression of OCN during the first 2
months was scattered occasionally. However, 3 months postimplantation, the most intense staining was obtained in the PGMI group.

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text:
Periosteum, a membrane that covers almost the whole surface of bone, is crucial in bone formation and defect healing. Periosteum transplantation is confronted with the challenges of availability, donor site morbidity, and immunological rejection.
Artificial periosteum fabricated from natural tissue or cell sheets are viable choice for the facilitation of bone regeneration cooperated with bone grafts; however, the fabrication complexity, high cost, and storage problems should be addressed for them.46 Electrospun fibers mimicking the fibrous structure of natural periosteum is therefore a novel approach to better treat
the large bone defects. Electrospun composite membranes based on silk fibroin had been fabricated to form a synthetic periosteum but the osteogenesis performance was limited when only relying on the recognition of synthetic materials by cells.47 Besides, a biomimetic tissue-engineered periosteum was constructed via layer-by-layer bottom-up strategy utilizing PCL, collagen, and nano-hydroxyapatite composite nanofiber sheets seeded with bone marrow stromal cells.48 However, the fabrication of biomimetic artificial periosteum with antibacterial and osteogenic dual functions for bone regeneration applications is still in their infancy. In this study, electrospun core-sheath fiber was thus used to mimic the architecture and osteogenesis function of natural periosteum, accompanied by the bestowal of effective bacteriostasis function. Both the core-sheath configuration and different degradation rates of the fiber core and fiber shell were designed to provide favorable contributions for the controlled and hierarchical release of antibacterial agent MOX in the fiber shell and osteogenic agent ICA in the fiber core. The physical property and biological property of the electrospun dual drugloaded core-sheath fiber membrane were investigated comprehensively to better understand its clinic outcome.
SEM and TEM confirmed the successful fabrication of the electrospun core-sheath micro/nano fiber membrane. After the crosslinking of gelatin by genipin, the fiber morphology and porous structure still remained. The pore sizes of the fibrous membrane are much smaller than those of the fibroblasts, which could prevent the migration of fibroblasts to the defect sites. Furthermore, the 60–90% porosities of all the fibrous membranes could sufficiently ensure gas and nutrition exchange.49
XRD characterization clarified the homogeneous dispersion of MOX and ICA in the polymer matrix that would benefit the controlled and sustained drug release. The stretchability and high tensile strength of PGMI further facilitated its practical application in clinics.50 The improvement in surface hydrophilicity for PGM and PGMI compared to PG micro/nano fiber membrane was primarily ascribed to the addition of MOX that is hydrophilic owing to the presence of a carboxyl group. Surface wettability affects proteins adsorption significantly and could possibly supply beneficial cues for biomaterials to interact with dynamic tissues.51
Our primary findings are that the electrospun core-sheath fiber composed of PCL core and gelatin shell can act as an effective carrier for MOX and ICA. The mechanism of drug release was based on drug diffusion and matrix degradation.52 These two drugs exhibited burst release during the first day, and were attributable to the drug diffusion in the fiber surface. The gelatin in the fiber shell was directly interfacing with PBS such that the release profiles of the encapsulated MOX in PGM and PGMI was similar. Meanwhile, the diffusion and release of MOX from the fiber shell would lead to small channels and defects in fiber, which could be favorable for water molecules to diffuse into the fiber core and finally facilitate ICA diffusion to the fiber surface. Therefore, it was reasonable that an evident difference was observed between the release rates of ICA in PGI and PGMI. In brief, the release of MOX in the fiber shell was not influenced by ICA in the fiber core; however, the release of ICA in the fiber core could be facilitated by the release of MOX in the fiber shell. The hierarchical release of MOX and ICA were
achieved in PGMI based on the core-sheath configuration and the disparate degradation rate of PCL and gelatin. A longer diffusion path cooperated with a slow degradation rate of PCL contributed to the sustained release of ICA; in contrast, MOX in the fiber shell was released in a fast and high-dose manner until 1 month, as a result from the shorter drug diffusion path and rapid degradation rate of gelatin.53 The first week post-surgery presented a high infection risk; therefore, a high dose of antibiotics was desired, while bone-inductive factors would be necessary during the whole regeneration period. We conclude that the release profiles of MOX and ICA in PGMI could reduce the infection risk effectively once the defect was formed and simultaneously provide sustained osteoinductive factors for the long-term defect healing.
It is also necessary for implantable scaffold to synchronize matrix degradation with the replacement of regenerated tissues. The artificial periosteum was preferable to be used for at least 2 months to allow the successful regeneration of bone tissues.54 In the first 10 days, the mass loss was mainly primarily ascribed to drug release and/or the hydrolysis of gelatin on the fiber surface. From 10 to 20 days, the degradation of cross-linked gelatin in the fiber shell led to a sharp mass decrease in the polymer matrix. Subsequently, the mass loss was primarily resulted from PCL hydrolysis and degradation accompanied by a slow ICA release. MOX is water soluble and the encapsulation of MOX in the fiber shell accelerated the degradation significantly because the resulting defects from MOX release on the fiber surface would open more channels for water exchange. Briefly, the electrospun core-sheath fiber membrane could provide effective antibacterial cues during the first month and sustained osteoinductive cues for the entire duration while degrading gradually without interference to normal tissues. The in vitro antibacterial and cytotoxicity evaluation also proved that MOX released from the fiber shell could prevent the colonization of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria without any side effects on the cells. Moreover, the cells could adhere to and proliferate on the electrospun membrane despite the use of organic solvents, antibiotics, and crosslinking agents.
We also confirmed that the sustained release of ICA was beneficial for the osteogenic differentiation especially for OCN expression and Ca2+ deposition.55 It has also been reported that the antibiotics adversely impact cell viability and osteogenic activity.56 In our study, the encapsulation of MOX adversely affected the ALP expression, but the OCN expression and Ca2+ deposition were up-regulated significantly in PGM. The positive effect of MOX encapsulation in the fiber shell on OCN and Ca2+ expression was speculated to be the enhanced perception of matrix-driven cues on hydrophilic fibers.57 Furthermore, a significantly higher ALP, OCN expression, and calcium deposition were observed in all fiber membranes compared with TCP, thus confirming the active role of the ECM-like structure features of the fiber membrane. The most remarkable capability on promoting osteogenic differentiation was demonstrated in the PGMI group among all fiber membranes owing to the synergistic effect of hydrophilic MOX and powerful osteogenic promoter ICA, thus indicating its potential to be applied as artificial periosteum.
The in vivo experiments further demonstrated the effective role of the electrospun dual drug-loaded membrane as an
artificial periosteum. All results from radiographic observation, histological, and immunohistochemical analysis indicated that PGMI possessed the most positive effect in enhancing the quality and quantity of bone formation as well as maturation when compared to the blank and PG groups. The comprehensive effect of fibrous matrix and hierarchical release of MOX and ICA both facilitated in obtaining the nascent bone with high quantity and quality, thus highlighting the great potential of this electrospun MOX- and ICA-loaded core-sheath fibrous membrane to be applied as an artificial periosteum in practice.
To summarize, we have developed a fibrous membrane with ICA and MOX encapsulated within a PCL core and gelatin shell, respectively, assisted by co-axial electrospinning. Through rational design of fiber configuration and polymer component, a biomimetic periosteum was designed that could provide antibacterial and osteogenic cues for bone regeneration. The fast release of MOX and sustained release of ICA could effectively inhibit bacterial colonization and simultaneously provide osteoinductive cues for bone regeneration by virtue of the core-sheath configuration and disparate degradation rate of PCL and gelatin. The electrospun fibrous membrane with the required mechanical strength and biocompatibility was also a viable supporting substrate for MC3T3-E1 cells to adhere to and proliferate on. Furthermore, the dual drug-loaded core-sheath fiber membrane clearly enhanced the in vitro osteogenic differentiation of MC3T3-E1 cells including the osteocalcin and type-I collagen expression as well as calcium deposition. Further, the MOX- and ICA-loaded core-sheath fiber membrane displayed fascinating properties contributing to the in vivo bone formation in a rabbit radius defect model. Therefore, we believe that the ICA- and MOX-loaded core-sheath fiber membrane is promising as a multifunctional artificial periosteum for bone regeneration applications in clinics.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sections.text: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nano.2019.01.002.

referenceMentions.context: Bone defects, particularly critical sized, remain a major challenge in the clinical field.(1) Periosteum plays indispensable roles in bone formation and defect healing.

Nanomedicine: NBM 2019;17:1 genitor cells that contribute to normal bone growth, healing, and remodeling.(2) However, the availability of natural periosteum is limited because it can only be surgically separated from the bones of individuals.

However, the availability of natural periosteum is limited because it can only be surgically separated from the bones of individuals.(3) This limitation underlines the clinical need to develop a new substitute that can mimic the natural periosteum's structure and functions.

Recently, Natural tissue or cell sheets have emerged as new strategies to construct periosteal substitute.(4) Nevertheless, the fabrication complexity and high cost of cellsderived periosteum has resulted in the urgency to facilitate the acquisition and convenient usage of artificial periosteum.

Because conventional osteogenic growth factors exhibit disadvantages of rapid degradation, high cost, and deactivation issues, it is unsurprising that the clinical use of these growth factors has been limited.(21) Nanomaterials have been studied extensively in the medical field for applications of drugs and genes carriers,(22) cancer therapy,(23) gene therapy, antibacterial agents, antiviral agents,(29) tissue engineering,(30) medical diagnosis,(31) medical imaging,(32) etc.
, and have advanced the development of medicine and biology significantly.(33) However, the biosafety of nanomaterials have always been the most concerning issue in recent years.

However, the biosafety of nanomaterials have always been the most concerning issue in recent years.(34) Furthermore, studies that emphasized on the synergistic effect of antibacterial and osteogenesis in the process of bone regeneration are still in their infancy.

Infections typically occur in the early stage of bone defect healing while osteogenesis is a long-term pathological activity after the inflammation period.(17) Thus, the appropriate and sequential release of antibacterial and osteogenesis agents would be highly desirable for biomaterials to match with the process of bone tissue regeneration.

Genipin, an excellent natural biosafety cross-linker, was used to crosslink the gelatin in the fiber shell owing to its fast degradation, as reported in our previous study.(37) Both the coresheath configuration and the disparate degradation rate of PCL and gelatin can contribute to the hierarchical release of the two encapsulated drugs.

The fiber diameters, pore sizes, apparent density, and porosity of the membranes were measured and calculated according to previous studies' description.(38) Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100F) was used to confirm the core-sheath configuration of the electrospun fibers.
Tensile test was conducted using the BOSE ElectroForce 3200 test instrument.(39) The water contact angles (WCAs) of the membranes were measured using the SL200A contact angle analyzer (China).

High-performance liquid chromatography was used to quantify the drug content in PBS.(40) The in vitro degradation evaluation of the electrospun membrane was performed simultaneously as the drug release tests.
The absorbance of the solution was read at 540 nm, as reported in a previous study.(42)

Histological analysis The histological analysis of the regenerated bone tissue was performed as reported previously.(43) Briefly, the samples were successively fixed, decalcified, dehydrated, embedded in paraffin, and sectioned to slices of 5 μm thickness.

COL I is an important structural component in the bone matrix and affects the mineralized tissue's strength and toughness significantly.(45) No significant difference for the COL I expression was observed among the different groups after 14 days of culture (Figure 5, C).

Artificial periosteum fabricated from natural tissue or cell sheets are viable choice for the facilitation of bone regeneration cooperated with bone grafts; however, the fabrication complexity, high cost, and storage problems should be addressed for them.(46) Electrospun fibers mimicking the fibrous structure of natural periosteum is therefore a novel approach to better treat

Electrospun composite membranes based on silk fibroin had been fabricated to form a synthetic periosteum but the osteogenesis performance was limited when only relying on the recognition of synthetic materials by cells.(47) Besides, a biomimetic tissue-engineered periosteum was constructed via layer-by-layer bottom-up strategy utilizing PCL, collagen, and nano-hydroxyapatite composite nanofiber sheets seeded with bone marrow stromal cells.

Besides, a biomimetic tissue-engineered periosteum was constructed via layer-by-layer bottom-up strategy utilizing PCL, collagen, and nano-hydroxyapatite composite nanofiber sheets seeded with bone marrow stromal cells.(48) However, the fabrication of biomimetic artificial periosteum with antibacterial and osteogenic dual functions for bone regeneration applications is still in their infancy.

Furthermore, the 60–90% porosities of all the fibrous membranes could sufficiently ensure gas and nutrition exchange.(49) XRD characterization clarified the homogeneous dispersion of MOX and ICA in the polymer matrix that would benefit the controlled and sustained drug release.

The stretchability and high tensile strength of PGMI further facilitated its practical application in clinics.(50) The improvement in surface hydrophilicity for PGM and PGMI compared to PG micro/nano fiber membrane was primarily ascribed to the addition of MOX that is hydrophilic owing to the presence of a carboxyl group.

Surface wettability affects proteins adsorption significantly and could possibly supply beneficial cues for biomaterials to interact with dynamic tissues.(51) Our primary findings are that the electrospun core-sheath fiber composed of PCL core and gelatin shell can act as an effective carrier for MOX and ICA.

The mechanism of drug release was based on drug diffusion and matrix degradation.(52) These two drugs exhibited burst release during the first day, and were attributable to the drug diffusion in the fiber surface.

A longer diffusion path cooperated with a slow degradation rate of PCL contributed to the sustained release of ICA; in contrast, MOX in the fiber shell was released in a fast and high-dose manner until 1 month, as a result from the shorter drug diffusion path and rapid degradation rate of gelatin.(53) The first week post-surgery presented a high infection risk; therefore, a high dose of antibiotics was desired, while bone-inductive factors would be necessary during the whole regeneration period.

The artificial periosteum was preferable to be used for at least 2 months to allow the successful regeneration of bone tissues.(54) In the first 10 days, the mass loss was mainly primarily ascribed to drug release and/or the hydrolysis of gelatin on the fiber surface.

We also confirmed that the sustained release of ICA was beneficial for the osteogenic differentiation especially for OCN expression and Ca deposition.(55) It has also been reported that the antibiotics adversely impact cell viability and osteogenic activity.

It has also been reported that the antibiotics adversely impact cell viability and osteogenic activity.(56) In our study, the encapsulation of MOX adversely affected the ALP expression, but the OCN expression and Ca deposition were up-regulated significantly in PGM.

The positive effect of MOX encapsulation in the fiber shell on OCN and Ca expression was speculated to be the enhanced perception of matrix-driven cues on hydrophilic fibers.(57) Furthermore, a significantly higher ALP, OCN expression, and calcium deposition were observed in all fiber membranes compared with TCP, thus confirming the active role of the ECM-like structure features of the fiber membrane.

metadata.abstractText: The traditional Chinese medicine icariin (ICA) and broad-spectrum antibacterial drug moxifloxacin hydrochloride (MOX) were introduced into a polycaprolactone core and gelatin shell, respectively, to develop osteogenic and antibacterial biomimetic periosteum by coaxial electrospinning. The physical properties, drug release, degradation, antibacterial property, in vitro and in vivo osteogenesis performances were investigated. Results demonstrated that stepwise and controlled drug release profiles were achieved based on the coreshell configuration and disparate degradation rate of PCL and gelatin. Only 20% ICA was released from this dual drug-loaded membrane after 1 month while the release of MOX was almost completed. Moreover, clear in vitro antibacterial effect and enhancement in osteogenic marker expressions including osteocalcin, type-I collagen expression, and calcium deposition were observed. Notably, the dual drug-loaded membrane displayed fascinating properties contributing to in vivo bone formation in terms of quality and quantity in a rabbit radius defect model. © 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
